comments.commentBody: This terrific story ran one day after the Las Vegas bout and on a Sunday, when more NYT readers could see it and be stirred by it.  Makes sense to me.
This is horrifc.  Why did the NYT wait until after the big fight to run this?

Can you imagine a multimillionaire like Muhammad Ali allowed or encouraged his daughter to become a boxer when he had the resources, connections and money to steer her in many other rewarding directions?  After his  own brain was mashed by the occupation why would he allow his talented, intelligent, attractive daughter Laila risk her health and future in this brutal endeavor?
Wrestling, track, cross country, ballet, charitable work.

Wonderful. When do you plan on starting a soccer league in the inner city of Detroit?  Because those are the kids who are being served by boxing programs like the Downtown Boxing Gym Youth Program, which also provides academic tutoring and school support.  I'm sure the soccer program you have planned to replace the boxing you find so icky will be just as dedicated.

Soccer also requires a large field in a safe space, and as far as safety goes, plenty of concussions occur in games and practices. Not that I'm a fan of boxing, but I don't think soccer is going to be the wave of the future for disadvantaged kids.

Boxing saves lives.  Young people who find that boxing inspires them and gives them a purpose also end up learning discipline, dedication, and perseverance.  These are often kids who are not getting that kind of guidance through school or, sometimes, even at home.  Boxing tends to draw kids with few opportunities. Those of you posting here who would condemn boxing, ban boxing: what are you proposing to replace it?  If you are eager to get rid of boxing, to deny these young people the one activity that is giving them pride and keeping them off the streets, then you certainly must also be planning to provide an alternative.  What is the alternative you have in mind for these young people and when do you plan to get to work on it?

What kind of 'civilization' glories in such a blood sport?  At least have the decency to mandate protective gear and tighter controls to protect modern gladiators.  Professional football isn't too far behind with the propensity for physical injuries, sometimes inflicted intentionally.  Even the most successful athletes end up with lifelong injuries that do not reflect favorably on who or what  we are.

How will any amount of money ever make up for the loss of life and limb in this young man? This is scandalous. He probably was so dazed and fought reflexibly that he was unaware that he was being pummeled to death in the ring. Oh, my heart aches at the stupid barbarity.

If the NYT stops covering and reporting on such stories, then many of its readers would likely be ignorant of the potential devastating consequences of boxing matches. I am admittedly a fan of Manny Pacquiao and regularly read boxing stories regarding him. Yet I did not know about Mago's current state, though I had read snippets about his injuries from the Perez fight. From this article and Internet searches I conducted as a result, I leaneed about journeyman fighter Frankie Leal's death days after being knocked out in a fight, succumbing  to injuries he sustained in that battle. Articles like these serve an important purpose. Otherwise, many - even boxing fans - are left in the dark and no good can come out of that.

In short, there is an excellent reason for the rich suburbs like Marin and Westerchester to have voted 65-70% for Obama and the lower and middle income whites to vote 65% Republican.   Economic self-interest has a major impact on voting behavior.

This recipe was very tasty.  But, while I understand the reason to leave the shell on the shrimp (juicier and tastier), I don't like a dinner where I am trying to relax but I have to get my hands dirty shelling the shrimp as I eat.  So I made this with shelled shrimp but didn't boil it--just cooked it in a little water and butter.  Maybe not as good a dish as with unshelled shrimp but very tasty for those of us who don't like hassling with the shells.

Is the absence of information about the cause of death, "dreadful", when a man dies while on vacation in a foreign country on Friday and today is Sunday? Is it really so awful that you don't have that information? Or is there a group of trolls who are trying to sully his and his wife's reputation by implying something sinister?

It boggles the mind how anyone can read about Mr. Goldberg's generosity and support for his wife's career and decide to go on a forum and attempt to trash the guy. It's sickening.

The quasiperiodicity is only in the eye of the naive. Long records make it go away.

All good global temperature products give essentially the same result.

The linear trend is what it is.

The photos are showing up very small on my screen, especially the first two, not a lot bigger than thumbnail. I don't usually have this problem. Anyone else have the same thing? Does it have anything to do with the Virgin Atlantic ad on the right hand side?
Given what his father told him, it didn't sound like he had much of a choice.

I know that the Facebook/SV set isn't known for sharing much and is all thumbs when it comes to media interactions, but it's still nothing short of utterly bizarre and remarkably unusual that days later we have no idea of the country he died in (which would provide many useful leads) or any speculation, however slight, about the possible cause and circumstances of his death.  People looking for news are disappointed and many rightfully suspect a cover-up.

Out of 147 comments, approx. 20 writers imply that there is something fishy about the fact that the cause of death hasn't been revealed. That's a troll campaign if I ever saw one. The fact that it's only been 48 hours since he died and today is a Sunday, hasn't deterred these unhappy people.

RIP Dave Goldberg. What a mensch!
Headgear affects your peripheral vision and isn't there to protect anything but the hands of the other fighter.
Watch something els. I don't like MMA but I'm not campaign for a ban . I just don't watch it ; problem solved .

Something is very wrong here.

I am not at all a fan of boxing. I have no interest in a so called sport where the object is the beat on another human being with the goal of knocking him senseless or knocking him out.

Why can't all sanctioned boxing matches have the competitions wear protective head gear and more cushioned boxing gloves like is done in the Olympics? Olympic boxing seems to be pretty popular in spite of the protective equipment.
Breaks your heart, and my God Dan Barry can write, and make us see and feel this. So many good writers at the NYT.
Strength!! God help!!

I come from a line of London champion boxers - some of whom were also highly skilled at fighting for purses on the street. My father was a british army middleweight champion.

Boxing is intended to cause injury. Thats the point of it. The weak people in the audience might light to gloss over that - as you have done - but that's the fact. Where I come from boxing was not a "sport", it was a necessity and a way of life. But that way of life is over and gone. All that remains of boxing is the people who live off it like parasites and promote it as a "sport" and the people who watch and do not comprehend what they are watching. Both are weak types of people who do not understand boxing and never will. Both should be deprived of the opportunity to do that..

When an athlete is injured in swimming and dressage, it means there has been an accident. When a boxer is injured it is because his opponent succeeded did what the crowd came to see: watch one man beat another man senseless.

I can't see how anyone can "enjoy" watching this sport. Actually I question the use of the word enjoy here. But you are right, it's a personal choice. How anyone can pay for and enjoy two people hurting and maiming each other is beyond me.

Not unexpectedly, there is a great deal of tsking-tsking from the readers of The NYT about this tragic story along with the predicable calls to ban boxing (and football, too, I guess).

Athletes get injured in every sport, sometimes quite seriously. This includes sports like swimming and dressage (anyone remember the cause of Christopher Reeve's terrible injury?) which are, presumably, more acceptable to the high-minded readers here. Boxers know the risks and have the right to take them. There is such a thing as an illegal punch in boxing, among other rules, and the onus falls upon the referees to enforce those. Illegal or underhanded moves can cause real injury to opponents in any sport.

I'd also add that I was at the heavyweight match at Madison Sq Garden two weeks ago and thoroughly enjoyed it. The boxers were pros and had a clean, entertaining fight from which each walked away healthily. The crowd was surprisingly diverse, with many women in attendance who seemed to be enjoying themselves.

In my view, there is entirely too much judgement of the fans and the sport going on here masquerading as compassion for Mago. If you don't want to box, don't do it. If you don't want to see it, don't watch it. Don't assume to make those choices for others.

This should be the sports page lead story and the first page story above the fold. There is nothing noble or admirable about a sport that pits one fugitive from poverty against another, with the goal of rendering each other senseless, or dead.
If someone starts a website with a fund for him, I will donate to it.  Can one of you tech experts set up a site for donations...?
The question is, why do we as a culture appreciate watching people beat each other to a pulp? Why do we have such an appetite for violence? So much so that this fight wasnt stopped.

No, no, no. That's not how to help.

How to help is to pass laws or a national concord that says a small percentage of every boxing purse has to go into a managed fund to support the boxers injured by their game -- just as the NFL has bought its way out of multitudes of law suits with its recently approved settlement with former players.
Here's a man, and family, that came to the US with a dream.  And I think he needs our help.  There's a lotta people in the US.  If we each give $1, we can help.  How do we organize it?

Women make up a large percentage of the audience that watches such sports. At any rate, you're a few million years too late. It started when the first dinosaur bone was used as a club. Pick another battle. You lost this one.

I have become revolted by the culture of violence in this country, evidenced by (among other things) two of the most popular and staggeringly lucrative "sports" -- football and boxing. Men beating on each other until they are brain damaged. Spectators paying millions - billions - to see it happen. Wife-beating boxers and NFL players held up as heroes and being paid millions for their belligerence. Owners and promoters who see and care about nothing but the money. Testosterone run rampant. I expect the world would be a much kinder and bearable place if it were run by women.

as an emergency room and trauma nurse this is very sad.
the medical staff at ringside should be trained and astute enough to anticipate and triage head injury during the "game".
i pray the family can recoup some financial compensation for what appears to be outright incompetence.
again, this story is a day late.
Where is Popeye now that we need him?

Dr W, we got SAM I YAM.

Martin, I'm like humming The Girl from Ipomoea, and think that Dioscorea is the condition with a pathognomonic runny Diosco. True?
L, I should have Seussed that ....  :-)

Deb: Since you mention being pedantic, I'll chime in by pointing out that a YAM is exactly what a "Sweet potato" is not. (I know, I know, Web Coll Dict gives sweet potato as a third definition of yam, but that must surely be based on the preponderance of ignorant misusage of the word.)

This seems to speak to the gullibility of some evangelicals. they loyally support the party that consistently lies to them, makes false promises and empty gestures, gets it wrong all the time on nearly every domestic and international issue and all the while the leaders enrich themselves at the expense of their constituents. Having faith is wonderful, but when you leave logic at the door, people just take advantage of you, like the GOP has been doing for a couple of decades now with the christian evangelical movement.

We go in to "defend our and their interests" whatever and wherever they are, such as Africa. The Chinese go in to partner with the population there to fund infrastructure and finance production of resources from agriculture to mining. We spend our resources which are usually for defense of those governments which and obtain nothing except ill feelings in the end. The Chinese derive long term benefits which will benefit their own populace as well as those in their benefitted countries. We had better learn from our past mistakes, to plan long term for the future like the Chinese.

The same holds true in Antartica, Arctic and space, where we are also, sadly lagging. We need a Congress and a President to look past the next budget cycle and their next reelection to perpetuate themselves, and look long term for the future of our country and our children, lest we become a third world power, as we watch China and others surpass us on the highway of the future.

Hooray emus! You fixed that percent code conversion! Maybe this URL that failed yesterday will work now.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keyser_S%C3%B6ze
Yep it works.  I had no Idea that was giving problems.

Yes, those percent codes represent problematic characters in URLs and were necessary for the emus to leave alone if they weren't going to update their table of permitted characters.

Codes for ö
256-char: %F6
Unicode: %C3%B6

Wikipedia supports them both so this URL also works:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keyser_S%F6ze

Deb,

Sometimes I am surprised by the HTML supported on this blog. I'll give MOT/HER a shot with the PRE tag. Just because we can't use it doesn't mean your more robust bag of tricks won't.
MOT
HER
